In the upper eyelid it blends with the tendon of the [[Levator palpebrÃ¦ superioris]], and in the lower eyelid with the [[Tarsus (eyelids)|tarsal plate]].<ref> Meyer DR, Linberg JV, Wobig JL, et al.: Anatomy of the orbital septum and associated eyelid connective tissues. Ophthalmic Plast Reconstr Surg 7:104, 1991 </ref>
â
When the eyes are closed, the whole orbital opening is covered by the septum and tarsi. Medially it is thin, and, becoming separated from the [[medial palpebral ligament]], attaches to the lacrimal bone at its [[posterior lacrimal crest|posterior crest]]. The medial ligament and its much weaker lateral counterpart, attached to the septum and orbit, keep the lids stable as the eye moves. <ref> "eye, human."EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica. 2008. EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica 2006 Ultimate Reference Suite DVD 2008" </ref>
+
When the eyes are closed, the whole orbital opening is covered by the septum and tarsi. Medially it is thin, and, becoming separated from the [[medial palpebral ligament]], attaches to the lacrimal bone at its [[posterior lacrimal crest|posterior crest]]. The medial ligament and its much weaker lateral counterpart, attached to the septum and orbit, keep the lids stable as the eye moves. <ref> "eye, human."EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica. 2008. [[EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica 2006 Ultimate Reference Suite DVD]] 2008" </ref>
The septum is perforated by the vessels and nerves which pass from the orbital cavity to the [[face]] and [[scalp]].
The septum is perforated by the vessels and nerves which pass from the orbital cavity to the [[face]] and [[scalp]].
